channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: US 'spied on French presidents'
item.description: The US National Security Agency spied on French Presidents Jacques Chirac, Nicolas Sarkozy and Francois Hollande in 2006-12, the Wikileaks website says.

item.title: Greek PM bids to seal debt deal
item.description: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras heads to Brussels to meet creditors ahead of a summit designed to seal a deal to avoid a Greek debt default.

item.title: World 'largely favours' US and Obama
item.description: The US is viewed favourably by two-thirds of people surveyed by Pew in 40 countries, up on previous years, but its interrogation methods remain unpopular.

item.title: Armenians stage renewed protests
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators in the Armenian capital Yerevan take part in renewed protests against rising electricity prices.

item.title: Rebel flag protests spread across US
item.description: Four US states join South Carolina in calling on the withdrawal of the Confederate battle flag, after a church shooting thought to be racially motivated.

item.title: Queen 'could move out of palace'
item.description: The Queen may have to move out of Buckingham Palace temporarily to allow maintenance work costing Â£150m to be carried out, royal officials say.

item.title: Police raid Toyota after arrest
item.description: Police raid the offices of Toyota Motor after the arrest of Julie Hamp, a senior American executive, on alleged drug offences.

item.title: Ebola crisis 'harming malaria fight'
item.description: The Ebola epidemic in Guinea that began early last year has set back the country's fight against malaria, say experts.

item.title: Pakistan heatwave deaths cross 800
item.description: The death toll from a heatwave in Pakistan's southern Sindh province has passed 800, hospital officials say, with mortuaries reaching their capacity.

item.title: Nigeria town hit by 'girl bomber'
item.description: A girl aged about 12 is reported to have killed at least 10 people in a suicide attack in Nigeria's north-eastern Yobe state.

item.title: UK border pledge over Calais migrants
item.description: Border security is stepped up in northern France and Dover after migrants desperate to reach the UK tried to exploit ferry strike action in Calais.

item.title: Mushroom 'helps keep fat off'
item.description: A mushroom used for centuries in Chinese medicine reduces weight gain in animals, say researchers in Taiwan.

item.title: VIDEO: 'A family destroyed' by Yemen air strikes
item.description: A BBC team has travelled to the heart of Yemen's civil war, where the ongoing fighting has brought untold suffering to its people.

item.title: VIDEO: Moment Charleston suspect arrested
item.description: Dashcam footage has emerged of the moment Charleston suspect Dylann Roof was arrested.

item.title: VIDEO: Islamic State 'launches currency'
item.description: Pictures are circulating online - thought to be the first look at currency issued by the Islamic State group.

item.title: VIDEO: White Horse hero's fall from grace
item.description: The task of managing China's turbulent change creates enormous pressures on the individuals involved.

item.title: VIDEO: Plastic pink flamingo creator dies
item.description: The creator of the pink plastic flamingo Donald Featherstone has died aged 79.

item.title: VIDEO: The other Hamilton racing driver
item.description: Reigning Formula 1 champion Lewis Hamilton's brother Nicolas Hamilton has cerebral palsy and will become the first disabled driver to compete in the British Touring Car Championships this weekend.

item.title: VIDEO: What the world thinks of China v US
item.description: The United States and China currently have the world's biggest economies but which country does the rest of the world think will dominate in future?

item.title: VIDEO: Migrants jump on lorries at Calais
item.description: Many people in Calais who are attempting to enter the UK illegally are jumping on lorries, which are stuck in queues due to a port workers strike.

item.title: Saudi Yemen bombing a message to Iran
item.description: A three-month Saudi-led bombing campaign has failed to dislodge Houthi rebels in Yemen, but the campaign is intended to send a warning to Iran, says the BBC's Middle East correspondent Jeremy Bowen.

item.title: Moving ever closer to a new Cold War
item.description: With the US pre-positioning equipment in Europe, tensions between Nato and Russia are becoming ever more fraught, says Jonathan Beale.

item.title: Guns cast shadow over Obama presidency
item.description: James Coomarasamy looks at how Barack Obama's presidency has been clouded by gun issues - and wonders if there's still time to make any reforms?

item.title: Greece and migrants to dominate EU summit
item.description: Can EU leaders achieve a breakthrough on Greece or the migrant crisis? Laurence Peter examines this week's high-stakes summit in Brussels.

item.title: Brazil's biofuels hit new sweetspot
item.description: Could Brazil's biofuel industry has had to compete with subsidised petrol, but could it now see its day int he sun?

item.title: Should Greece leave the eurozone?
item.description: Hopes are rising that a deal can be struck to stop Greece defaulting on its debt, but would so-called "Grexit" be a disaster for the country?

item.title: US invests in 'Star Wars hoverbikes'
item.description: 'Star Wars'-style hover bikes could be coming to the US military after engineers in the UK and US struck a deal with the US Department of Defense.

item.title: Racehorses 'still getting quicker'
item.description: Racehorses are continuing to get quicker, a study of winning times spanning 165 years of racing indicates.

item.title: Miami Dolphins owner 'in $8bn F1 bid'
item.description: The owner of the Miami Dolphins American football team is reportedly working with investors from Qatar to buy a stake in Formula 1 racing.

item.title: Bouygues rejects Altice takeover bid
item.description: French telecoms group Bouygues rejects unanimously a near â¬10bn takeover offer by rival group Altice.

item.title: 'Pregnancy wi-fi' causes controversy
item.description: Two Chinese tech firms have clashed over a new wireless router with a special setting for pregnant women.

item.title: Man builds giant computer at home
item.description: For many tech companies the race is on to build ever smaller computer processors, but one British man has gone in the opposite direction.

item.title: Fifty Shades rewrite breaks sales record
item.description: EL James' new Fifty Shades of Grey spin-off breaks UK sales records in its first week, beating Dan Brown's The Lost Symbol.

item.title: RSC casts UK's 'best Bottoms'
item.description: The Royal Shakespeare Company announces that 14 amateur theatre groups will join a company of professionals on a national tour of A Midsummer Night's Dream.

item.title: England's wild beaver colony has kits
item.description: A female from the first wild beaver colony in England for hundreds of years has given birth to at least two young.

item.title: EU Sentinel satellite to track crops
item.description: The second of the European Union's Sentinel Earth-observing satellites launches on a mission that will allow scientists to map the performance of the world's crop harvests.

item.title: Pakistan heatwave deaths cross 700
item.description: The death toll from an ongoing heatwave in Pakistan's southern Sindh province has passed 700, local media report, as mortuaries reach capacity.

item.title: 'Organs-on-chips' wins design award
item.description: Silicon chips that mimic the function of living human organs win the Design of the Year award from the Design Museum in London.

item.title: England crush NZ to win Twenty20
item.description: Joe Root scores 68 as England thrash New Zealand by 56 runs in their one-off Twenty20 international at Old Trafford.

item.title: Liverpool complete Â£29m Firmino deal
item.description: Liverpool sign Brazil forward Roberto Firmino from Hoffenheim for a fee of about Â£29m, subject to a medical.

item.title: Our deep need for monsters that lurk in the dark
item.description: Sea monsters are the stuff of legend - lurking not just in the depths of the oceans, but also the darker corners of our minds. Why are we drawn to these creatures, asks Mary Colwell.

item.title: Getting close to my son who died on Air India 182
item.description: When a flight from Canada to India exploded in 1985, all 329 people on board were killed. But the most deadly bomb attack ever on a plane is now often forgotten.

item.title: Skinny jeans given health warning
item.description: Skinny jeans can seriously damage muscles and nerves, doctors say, citing the case of a woman who had to be cut out of a pair after her calves ballooned.

item.title: French fail to 'cope' with exam
item.description: Nearly 12,000 French teenagers sign a petition saying a baccalaureate English question was impossible to understand because of the word "cope".

item.title: Rwanda 'outrage' at spy chief arrest
item.description: The Rwandan government has called the UK arrest of their intelligence chief Karenzi Karake, who is wanted in Spain for war crimes, "an outrage".

item.title: Toxic alcohol 'supplier' arrested
item.description: Police in the Indian capital, Delhi, arrest a man who supplied the toxic alcohol which killed more than 100 people in the city of Mumbai.

item.title: EU reform to top Cameron-Merkel talks
item.description: David Cameron travels to Berlin later for talks on EU reform and other issues with Angela Merkel, ahead of an EU summit in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuela sets December poll date
item.description: Venezuela's election body sets the date of 6 December for legislative polls, following weeks of pressure from the opposition.

item.title: Kurds 'take key Syrian town from IS'
item.description: Kurdish fighters in northern Syria say they have captured a key town from Islamic State, just 50km from the group's headquarters at Raqqa.

item.title: 'Fast-track' trade bill clears hurdle
item.description: Legislation key to US President Barack Obama's trade agenda has passed a key hurdle in the Senate, just two weeks after it appeared to have failed.

item.title: Body of newborn baby found in river
item.description: Police seal off a section of an embankment in Cardiff after the body of a newborn baby is found in the River Taff.

item.title: Decision due on UK's fracking return
item.description: An application to start the first fracking operation in the UK for four years is to be decided later.

item.title: Scots struggling with funeral costs
item.description: A rising number of people in Scotland are struggling to pay for the funerals of their loved ones, according to Citizens Advice Scotland.

item.title: Fans pitch up as Glastonbury opens
item.description: Music fans begin setting up camp for the Glastonbury Festival after the gates opened for this year's festival.

item.title: In pictures: Guid Nychburris celebrations in Dumfries
item.description: Thousands turns out to watch the traditional parade

item.title: Lluniau: Traethau Cymru // Pictures: Wales's beaches
item.description: Some of Wales's finest beaches in pictures

item.title: In pictures: Faberge jewels
item.description: Items produced by Russian imperial jeweller Carl Faberge that feature in a new film.

item.title: In pictures: Africa's high coiffure
item.description: Beehives, braids and curled hair raised up like art installations at this year's Afrik show.

item.title: In pictures: World Yoga Day
item.description: Images from the first ever World Yoga Day.

item.title: In pictures: Thousands mark solstice
item.description: Some 23,000 people gathered at Stonehenge.

item.title: Your pictures: Alone
item.description: Readers' photographs on the theme of alone.

item.title: In pictures: Unseen Waterloo
item.description: Sam Faulkner's portraits commemorate the Battleâs bicentenary

item.title: The man who keeps finding new species of shark
item.description: How one man keeps finding new species

item.title: The fake revenge stunt that fooled nearly everyone
item.description: The fake divorce revenge stunt that went viral

item.title: Why solo dining can be tough for women in Delhi
item.description: A single woman solo dines in Delhi

item.title: Tango legend Carlos Gardel's posthumous journey home
item.description: The epic journey of a tango legend's body

item.title: Afghanistan's leaders face battle for peace
item.description: Has Afghan parliament attack dashed hopes for peace talks?

item.title: Why China warned the US to keep its distance
item.description: Why China told the US to keep away from this island
